docs.lead_paragraph: Rock stars, movie actresses and heads of state have shined a bright light on global poverty in the past year, often highlighting the particular burden on women, but a report from the United Nations released this week painstakingly details the huge gaps in data needed to understand how poverty -- in all its ugly guises -- affects women. Many poor countries simply do not collect the most basic facts about births, marriages and deaths by sex and age, or the employment status and wages of men and women.

headline.main: U.N. Reports Lack of Data On Women In Poverty

docs.snippet: According to a United Nations report, many poor countries do not collect basic facts about births, marriages and deaths by sex and age.

docs.lead_paragraph: Think of it as the fight for the Bionic Baby Boomer. From head to toe, aging boomers are being kept alive and kicking -- or at least walking -- by an expanding array of devices that combine the newest medical knowledge with the latest breakthroughs in digital electronics and material sciences.

headline.main: To Order Spare Parts Press *P; Medical Devices Are Hot, Which Is Why Guidant Is

docs.snippet: As wave after wave of baby boomers enter their prime health care spending years, the medical device market is expected to grow by double digits for years to come.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the confirmation of Judge Samuel Alito to the Supreme Court all but certain, it's becoming accepted wisdom that Roe v. Wade, the landmark 1973 decision granting women the right to abortion, is likely soon to be reversed.

Wade, the landmark 1973 decision granting women the right to abortion, is likely soon to be reversed. I'm not sure, though, that Roe really will be overturned by an Alito (and John Roberts) court. docs.lead_paragraph: On a Winter Evening Walk, The Calls of the Wild When Mike Feller calls, owls listen. The reason is simple: owls like to be wooed, and Mr. Feller is something of a professional suitor. ''This time of year, they're courting,'' he explained, noting that male and female owls call to one another. ''I've had good luck getting screech owls to come in very close, and great horned owls also respond.''
docs.abstract: Laurel Graeber Family Fare column discusses twilight walk for owl viewing at Pelham Bay Park, Wingspan Arts Kids Film Festival at Walter Reade Theater, Manhattan, and New York Philharmonic Very Young People's Concert at Merkin Concert Hall, Manhattan; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KETCHUM, Idaho, is a rare, strange small town. Home to the Sun Valley ski resort, Ketchum is populated by two types of people: the rich and the not-rich. In the first category are the super-stratospherically wealthy, who own ranches and huge houses and no longer even associate with people who fly commercial; the Hollywood stars, who may be famous but truth be told are generally pretty poor compared to the previous group; and the plain vanilla well-to-do, who own a condo for family ski vacations.
docs.abstract: Alex Kuczynski Critical Shopper column describes Chateau Drug & True Value Hardware, catchall store in Ketchum, Idaho, that caters to super-rich and nonrich alike; mass retailers have been kept away from town that wants to preserve its downtown center of activity; celebrity sightings in Chateau are commonplace; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Chateau Drug is a misnomer: it does sells cough syrup and has an excellent pharmacy, panini presses, lip gloss, fishing lures and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE cold night 13 years ago Annie Duke drove from her home in Philadelphia, where she was a doctoral student, to her mother's apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, sat down to dinner and ate a bowl of rigatoni that set off an exhaustive reassessment of her ambitions. Ms. Duke got sick to her stomach, spent days unable to eat, decided this signaled a deeper crisis, questioned her plan for an academic career, married a friend she had never dated, moved with him to Columbus, Mont., and, not long after, started to play poker with men, few of whom had feminist leanings, at the Crystal Lounge in nearby Billings. It was there, she says in her recent memoir, ''Annie Duke: How I Raised, Folded, Bluffed, Flirted, Cursed and Won Millions at the World Series of Poker'' (Hudson Street Press), written with David Diamond, that she found her true purpose.

headline.main: Dealt A Bad Hand? Fold 'em. Then Raise.

docs.abstract: Interview with Annie Duke, winner of Tournament of Champions at World Series of Poker in Las Vegas, who is parlaying her success at poker table into new book, DVD and television show; she gives tour of her home in Hollywood Hills; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Last year the poker champion bought a sprawling Mediterranean-style home in the Hollywood Hills, which she is in the midst of refurbishing.

docs.lead_paragraph: There's no question that the amount of lead in children's blood has dropped significantly in recent decades, much to the benefit of their brains and bodies. There's also no question that children who are still being permanently damaged by excessive lead levels live mainly at the poverty level or near it, in neighborhoods where they can be poisoned by lead from contaminated paint, water, soil and dust. However, no one at any level of society, not even those with seven-figure incomes, can afford to be complacent about the exposure of children to lead in home and play environments.

headline.main: Dally No Longer: Get the Lead Out

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes sources of lead poisoning and discusses ways to minimize health risk, particularly for children; calls for tighter regulations and better testing for lead exposure; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The eight women sat in a semicircle facing a wooden cross, reflecting on the abortions they said they had never gotten over. Though they now opposed abortion, they criticized the demonstrators who protest outside clinics.

headline.main: Some Abortion Foes Forgo Politics for Quiet Talk

docs.snippet: A Kentucky Bible study for women coping after abortions represents a less-visible but wide aspect of the anti-abortion movement.

docs.lead_paragraph: When I began teaching at Yale Law School in 1998, a friend spoke to me frankly. ''You'll have a better chance at tenure,'' he said, ''if you're a homosexual professional than if you're a professional homosexual.'' Out of the closet for six years at the time, I knew what he meant. To be a ''homosexual professional'' was to be a professor of constitutional law who ''happened'' to be gay. To be a ''professional homosexual'' was to be a gay professor who made gay rights his work. Others echoed the sentiment in less elegant formulations. Be gay, my world seemed to say. Be openly gay, if you want. But don't flaunt.
docs.abstract: Kenji Yoshino article says that while courts protect women and minority groups against discrimination as entire groups, they have yet to extend protection to subsets within groups that refuse to assimilate to dominant norms; discusses pressure he has felt as teacher at Yale University Law School to play down his gay identity and says same pressure to 'cover' is felt by other outsiders in society at large; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: Discrimination used to take aim at entire social groups. Now it is directed at the members of those groups who refuse to assimilate to the mainstream.

docs.lead_paragraph: EACH of the nine brief scenes in Rodrigo García's ''Nine Lives'' is a little epiphany that revolves around a different woman under emotional stress. Together they add up to a collection of wrenching, minutely observed moments that suggest Chekhov short stories. Each is written, acted and directed with such exquisite calibration of tone, subtext and body language that the performances seem less like acting than fleeting, revelatory moments of real life captured on film. The supermarket in which Diana (Robin Wright Penn) and Damian (Jason Isaacs), former lovers now pushing 40, run into each other by chance couldn't be a more banal setting for a shattering reunion. In the fluorescent glare, with barely audible Muzak humming in the background, they reconnect and within minutes dive into the murky emotional depths of their past.
docs.snippet: One brief scene in "Nine Lives" conveys more about its characters' inner lives than is revealed in most feature-length movies.
